NOTE: Please remove any links that Google automatically adds to your text.

quiz.questionTitle: “The days are gone forever when our enemies could blackmail us with nuclear bombs.”
quiz.response: In his first speech as North Korean leader, Kim talked up his father’s and grandfather’s achievements in building a nuclear program.

quiz.questionTitle: “The military might of a country represents its national strength. Only when it builds up its military might in every way can it develop into a thriving country.”
quiz.response: Kim began a tradition of New Year speeches in 2013, when he talked about improving North Korea’s economy by… you guessed it, building up the military.

quiz.questionTitle: “We must remain strong. Our enemies are looking for weakness.”
quiz.response: Donald Trump wrote this in a September 2011 tweet opposing cuts to military spending. At the time Congress was wrangling over how to slash the deficit (paywall).

quiz.questionTitle: “We have large groups of people that want to blow up every one of our cities, that want to destroy our country, that want to kill our people.”
quiz.response: In November 2015, Trump insisted that hundreds, if not thousands of Muslims “went wild” after 9/11, celebrating across the Hudson river. Called on to explain his claim, which is unsubstantiated by any evidence, he doubled down on his attacks on Islam.

quiz.questionTitle: “If invasive outsiders and provocateurs touch us even slightly, we will not be forgiving in the least and sternly answer with a merciless, holy war of justice.”
quiz.response: Kim’s 2016 New Year’s speech got bellicose. (And can you imagine Trump using words like “merciless holy war of justice”? OK, maybe you can.)

quiz.questionTitle: “Join me to fight our common enemies, to pursue our shared values, and to protect the dignity of every child.”
quiz.response: In May 2017, at the Israel Museum in Jerusalem, in the wake of the terrorist attack in Manchester, Trump made a call to the people of Israel to support the US in fighting terrorism.

quiz.questionTitle: “They are cannibals and homicides seeking pleasure in slaughter.”
quiz.response: When the US supported an effort to indict North Korean leaders for human-rights abuses in 2014, Kim stepped up “anti-American ideological education” by recalling US atrocities during the Korean war during the 1950s. (The cannibalism bit, at least, is his invention.)

quiz.questionTitle: “Our country is the greatest force for freedom the world has ever known. We have big hearts, big brains, and big guts—and we use all three.”
quiz.response: Trump shows his mastery of the rule of three in his 2011 book Time to Get Tough: Make America Great Again!

quiz.questionTitle: "We are willing to have talks in an open-minded manner with anyone who wants peace."
quiz.response: In his 2016 New Year’s speech, the dear leader appeared unusually conciliatory as he signaled his intention of opening up a dialogue with South Korea.

quiz.questionTitle: “You have seen the truth, you have spoken the truth, and the truth has now called us...to action.”
quiz.response: Trump rhapsodized on the “truth” of the horrors of communism in a speech in Miami in June, when announcing a policy shift on Cuba.

quiz.questionTitle: “Today this ship officially begins its role in the noble military history of our great nation.”
quiz.response: “ In a few moments, I will commission this wonderful, beautiful, but very, very powerful warship,” continued president Trump in his remarks during the commissioning ceremony for the USS Gerald R. Ford in July 2017.

quiz.questionTitle: “Let us bring about a radical turn in the building of an economic giant with the same spirit and mettle as were displayed in conquering space.”
quiz.response: This was Kim Jong-un’s first New Year’s address, in 2013, in which he talked of the need for economic growth while celebrating the country’s launch of a long-range rocket that had recently put a satellite into orbit.

meta.desc: See how good you are at telling the world’s two great nuclear saber-rattlers apart.
meta.overallFeedback: Now that you’ve got your nuclear rhetoric sharpened up, why not ask your friends to try the quiz?
